Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: A few machines are running hotter than normal after missing their last service window.
Story: I could see the frustration etched on Alex’s face as he slumped onto the couch, his shoulders heavy with the weight of another rough day at work. He barely looked up when I entered, and I knew he needed me—needed comfort, a listening ear, maybe just someone to sit quietly beside him. But my phone buzzed insistently in my pocket: a message from the plant manager. The machines on line three were overheating, and if I didn’t get there soon, we could be looking at a costly breakdown. I felt the tug in my chest, torn between the urge to drop everything and wrap Alex in my arms, and the responsibility gnawing at me to keep the machines running smoothly. Both needed me, right now, in different ways. My mind raced with the expectations—be the supportive girlfriend, be the reliable repairer. I stood frozen in the hallway, heart pounding, wishing I could split myself in two.
